Award.AwardTitle: Chain Dynamics and Layering within Polyelectrolyte Multilayer Films
Award.AbstractNarration:
TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Stratification of layer-by-layer (LbL) polyelectrolyte films lies in the heart of advanced biomedical and optical applications of polyelectrolyte multilayer (PEM) films, yet is often compromised by molecular diffusion and intermixing. In this project, fundamental correlations between dynamics of polymer chains and internal structure of PEMs will be explored, and this knowledge will be applied to develop strategies for the construction of stratified LbL PEM films and to study evolution of their structure during aging. Specifically, inter-chain dynamics will be explored in three cases: (1) in solution; (2) between solution and the films during multilayer construction; and (3) at a post-assembly step during aging of LBL films in humid or aqueous environments. Fluorescence correlation spectroscopy (FCS), a combination of FCS and in situ ATR-FTIR, and a combination of fluorescence recovery after pattern photobleaching (FRAPP) and neutron reflectivity (NR) will be applied for cases (1)- (3), respectively. The project involves synthesis of well-defined polybase-polyacid (PB-PA) pairs associated through ionic pairing or hydrogen-bonding. The central suggestion is that translational diffusion of polymers within PEMs is anisotropic, and proposed experiments aim to reveal the degree of this anisotropy as well as how this anisotropy evolves with time when PEM films are aged in high humidity environment or in aqueous solutions under varying temperature and/or ionic strength. The knowledge generated in this proposal can be used to predict interactions, motions, relaxations and order in a broad range of PEM films.

NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

This project provides knowledge of dynamics and structure of self-assembled polymer films, which will enable construction and prediction of aging of stratified polymer films for biomedical and optical applications. One example includes polymer coatings enabling sequential delivery of therapeutic compounds from the surface of a biomedical device or an implant. Importantly, this project will create a fertile training ground for the participating graduate students and summer undergraduate students in forefront issues of polymer science, a training ground further enriched by collaboration with NIST and ORNL. A new course on nanostructured polymers will be developed as part of the highly interdisciplinary Stevens Nanotechnology Graduate Program. A significant part of the project includes working with high school students from the Northern New Jersey area and disseminating knowledge through experimental demonstrations and poster exhibition involving K-12 high school students. Through existing close links with the K-12 ACS SEED and the Partners in Science Program NJ program, a new educational initiative will be developed. Specifically, by working with a recently started NSF-funded GK-12 initiative, New Jersey Alliance for Engineering Education (NJAEE), and with the Stevens Center for Innovation in Engineering and Science Education (CIESE), a teaching module Polymers in Our Life will be built and piloted in a high school setting. The module will be featured on the NJAEE website, and linked to the CIESE website, which enjoys hundreds of thousands of site visits by K-12 educators and students each year.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit. Understanding and controlling the structure of layer-by-layer (LbL) polymer films is critically important for applications of such films as antireflective coatings or sequential delivery of drugs from surfaces. This project has explored factors that affect the dynamics and the structure of LbL films. These factors include film composition (polymer type and molecular weight), pre-deposition or post-deposition solution conditions (pH and ionic strength), as well as processing techniques (spin- vs. dip-assisted film assembly). The main goal was to explore polymer chain dynamics and its effect on the internal structure of LbL assemblies. Using a combination of fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP) and neutron reflectivity (NR), we have found that (1) polycations with more steric bulk at charged groups had a higher propensity to intermix (Fig. 1); (2) diffusion of assembled polymer chains showed strong (factor of 103 -105) anisotropy in directions parallel and perpendicular to the substrate surface (Fig. 2); (3) for films assembled in the linear regime, the polymer diffusion coefficient was inversely proportional  to the chain length; and (4) the use of spin-assisted film deposition in place of dip-assembly led to smaller amounts of adsorbed polyelectrolytes within LbL films,  a higher degree of internal film order, slower polymer chain diffusion (Fig. 3), and dramatically improved film stability in salt solutions. Finally, we have quantitatively explored the effect of salt on diffusion of polyelectrolyte chains within LbL, and found that the polymer diffusion coefficients in directions both parallel and perpendicular to the substrate followed an exponential dependence on salt concentration. For the project duration, findings of our work have been described in fourteen papers, many presentations by graduate students at the ACS and APS meetings, as well as in twenty talks given by the PI at universities and international conferences.

Broader Impacts. Our findings significantly advance the understanding of the dynamics-structure relationship of LbL films, and, therefore, contribute to important areas of polymer physics and materials science. Moreover, the achieved capability to predict and manipulate internal layering within PEM films will enable unique applications of LbL films as antireflection coatings, films for sequential release of therapeutic compounds from the surface of an implant, or as asymmetric ‘smart’, free-standing films for actuation applications. Funding provided by NSF has helped to build and strengthen a core research unit to attract, educate, and train additional students, including those at the undergraduate level as well as high school students. The project has greatly enhanced the exposure of graduate students to modern aspects of polymer science. Students have additionally enriched their knowledge and experiences in their semiannual travels to Oak Ridge National Laboratory where they performed NR experiments and closely interacted with researchers. The PI’s group is also extensively involved in outreach activities with K-12 students.  Every summer the group has hosted one or more high-school students from underrepresented minorities through the ACS SEED program and another student through the Partners in Science Program associated with the Liberty Science Center (LSC) in Jersey City, NJ. For the project duration, four undergraduate and seven high school students (through support from the ACS SEED and NJ Liberty Science Center Programs) including six female and three male students from underrepresented minority groups. Summer scholars presented their research at the ACS national meetings as well as participated in several NJ competitions, where they received three awards.
